trans-unit.source: Process Data from SQL Azure | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Process Data from SQL Azure | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Process Data from SQL Azure
trans-unit.target: Process Data from SQL Azure

trans-unit.source: This document covers exploring data and generating features for data stored in a SQL Server VM on Azure.
trans-unit.target: This document covers exploring data and generating features for data stored in a SQL Server VM on Azure.

trans-unit.source: This can be done by data wrangling using SQL or by using a programming language like Python.
trans-unit.target: This can be done by data wrangling using SQL or by using a programming language like Python.

trans-unit.source: The sample SQL statements in this document assume that data is in SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: The sample SQL statements in this document assume that data is in SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: If it isn't, please refer to the cloud data science process map to learn how to move your data to SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: If it isn't, please refer to the cloud data science process map to learn how to move your data to SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: We describe the following data wrangling tasks in this section using SQL:
trans-unit.target: We describe the following data wrangling tasks in this section using SQL:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Exploration</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Exploration</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Feature Generation</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Feature Generation</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Here are a few sample SQL scripts that can be used to explore data stores in SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Here are a few sample SQL scripts that can be used to explore data stores in SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: For a practical example, you can use the <linkText>NYC Taxi dataset</linkText><title></title> and refer to the IPNB titled <linkText>NYC Data wrangling using IPython Notebook and SQL Server</linkText><title></title> for an end-to-end walk-through.
trans-unit.target: For a practical example, you can use the <linkText>NYC Taxi dataset</linkText><title></title> and refer to the IPNB titled <linkText>NYC Data wrangling using IPython Notebook and SQL Server</linkText><title></title> for an end-to-end walk-through.

trans-unit.source: Get the count of observations per day
trans-unit.target: Get the count of observations per day

trans-unit.source: SELECT CONVERT(date, ) as date, count(*) as c from group by CONVERT(date, )
trans-unit.target: SELECT CONVERT(date, ) as date, count(*) as c from group by CONVERT(date, )

trans-unit.source: Get the levels in a categorical column
trans-unit.target: Get the levels in a categorical column

trans-unit.source: select distinct from
trans-unit.target: select distinct from

trans-unit.source: Get the number of levels in combination of two categorical columns
trans-unit.target: Get the number of levels in combination of two categorical columns

trans-unit.source: select , ,count(*) from group by ,
trans-unit.target: select , ,count(*) from group by ,

trans-unit.source: Get the distribution for numerical columns
trans-unit.target: Get the distribution for numerical columns

trans-unit.source: select , count(*) from group by
trans-unit.target: select , count(*) from group by

trans-unit.source: In this section, we describe ways of generating features using SQL:
trans-unit.target: In this section, we describe ways of generating features using SQL:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Count based Feature Generation</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Count based Feature Generation</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Binning Feature Generation</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Binning Feature Generation</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Rolling out the features from a single column</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Rolling out the features from a single column</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Once you generate additional features, you can either add them as columns to the existing table or create a new table with the additional features and primary key, that can be joined with the original table.
trans-unit.target: Once you generate additional features, you can either add them as columns to the existing table or create a new table with the additional features and primary key, that can be joined with the original table.

trans-unit.source: This document demonstrates two ways of generating count features.
trans-unit.target: This document demonstrates two ways of generating count features.

trans-unit.source: The first method uses conditional sum and the second method uses the 'where` clause.
trans-unit.target: The first method uses conditional sum and the second method uses the 'where` clause.

trans-unit.source: These can then be joined with the original table (using primary key columns) to have count features alongside the original data.
trans-unit.target: These can then be joined with the original table (using primary key columns) to have count features alongside the original data.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to generate binned features by binning (using 5 bins) a numerical column that can be used as a feature instead:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to generate binned features by binning (using 5 bins) a numerical column that can be used as a feature instead:

trans-unit.source: In this section, we demonstrate how to roll-out a single column in a table to generate additional features.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we demonstrate how to roll-out a single column in a table to generate additional features.

trans-unit.source: The example assumes that there is a latitude or longitude column in the table from which you are trying to generate features.
trans-unit.target: The example assumes that there is a latitude or longitude column in the table from which you are trying to generate features.

trans-unit.source: Here is a brief primer on latitude/longitude location data (resourced from stackoverflow http://gis.stackexchange.com/questions/8650/how-to-measure-the-accuracy-of-latitude-and-longitude).
trans-unit.target: Here is a brief primer on latitude/longitude location data (resourced from stackoverflow http://gis.stackexchange.com/questions/8650/how-to-measure-the-accuracy-of-latitude-and-longitude).

trans-unit.source: This is useful to understand before featurizing the location field:
trans-unit.target: This is useful to understand before featurizing the location field:

trans-unit.source: The sign tells us whether we are north or south, east or west on the globe.
trans-unit.target: The sign tells us whether we are north or south, east or west on the globe.

trans-unit.source: A nonzero hundreds digit tells us we're using longitude, not latitude!
trans-unit.target: A nonzero hundreds digit tells us we're using longitude, not latitude!

trans-unit.source: The tens digit gives a position to about 1,000 kilometers.
trans-unit.target: The tens digit gives a position to about 1,000 kilometers.

trans-unit.source: It gives us useful information about what continent or ocean we are on.
trans-unit.target: It gives us useful information about what continent or ocean we are on.

trans-unit.source: The units digit (one decimal degree) gives a position up to 111 kilometers (60 nautical miles, about 69 miles).
trans-unit.target: The units digit (one decimal degree) gives a position up to 111 kilometers (60 nautical miles, about 69 miles).

trans-unit.source: It can tell us roughly what large state or country we are in.
trans-unit.target: It can tell us roughly what large state or country we are in.

trans-unit.source: The first decimal place is worth up to 11.1 km: it can distinguish the position of one large city from a neighboring large city.
trans-unit.target: The first decimal place is worth up to 11.1 km: it can distinguish the position of one large city from a neighboring large city.

trans-unit.source: The second decimal place is worth up to 1.1 km: it can separate one village from the next.
trans-unit.target: The second decimal place is worth up to 1.1 km: it can separate one village from the next.

trans-unit.source: The third decimal place is worth up to 110 m: it can identify a large agricultural field or institutional campus.
trans-unit.target: The third decimal place is worth up to 110 m: it can identify a large agricultural field or institutional campus.

trans-unit.source: The fourth decimal place is worth up to 11 m: it can identify a parcel of land.
trans-unit.target: The fourth decimal place is worth up to 11 m: it can identify a parcel of land.

trans-unit.source: It is comparable to the typical accuracy of an uncorrected GPS unit with no interference.
trans-unit.target: It is comparable to the typical accuracy of an uncorrected GPS unit with no interference.

trans-unit.source: The fifth decimal place is worth up to 1.1 m: it distinguish trees from each other.
trans-unit.target: The fifth decimal place is worth up to 1.1 m: it distinguish trees from each other.

trans-unit.source: Accuracy to this level with commercial GPS units can only be achieved with differential correction.
trans-unit.target: Accuracy to this level with commercial GPS units can only be achieved with differential correction.

trans-unit.source: The sixth decimal place is worth up to 0.11 m: you can use this for laying out structures in detail, for designing landscapes, building roads.
trans-unit.target: The sixth decimal place is worth up to 0.11 m: you can use this for laying out structures in detail, for designing landscapes, building roads.

trans-unit.source: It should be more than good enough for tracking movements of glaciers and rivers.
trans-unit.target: It should be more than good enough for tracking movements of glaciers and rivers.

trans-unit.source: This can be achieved by taking painstaking measures with GPS, such as differentially corrected GPS.
trans-unit.target: This can be achieved by taking painstaking measures with GPS, such as differentially corrected GPS.

trans-unit.source: The location information can can be featurized as follows, separating out region, location and city information.
trans-unit.target: The location information can can be featurized as follows, separating out region, location and city information.

trans-unit.source: Note that once can also call a REST end point such as Bing Maps API available at https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ff701710.aspx to get the region/district information.
trans-unit.target: Note that once can also call a REST end point such as Bing Maps API available at https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ff701710.aspx to get the region/district information.

trans-unit.source: The above location based features can be further used to generate additional count features as described earlier.
trans-unit.target: The above location based features can be further used to generate additional count features as described earlier.

trans-unit.source: You can programmatically insert the records using your language of choice.
trans-unit.target: You can programmatically insert the records using your language of choice.

trans-unit.source: You may need to insert the data in chunks to improve write efficiency [Check out the example of how to do this using pyodbc here](https://code.google.com/p/pypyodbc/wiki/AHelloWorldsampletoaccessmssqlwith_python).
trans-unit.target: You may need to insert the data in chunks to improve write efficiency [Check out the example of how to do this using pyodbc here](https://code.google.com/p/pypyodbc/wiki/AHelloWorldsampletoaccessmssqlwith_python).

trans-unit.source: Another alternative is to insert data in the database using <linkText>BCP utility</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Another alternative is to insert data in the database using <linkText>BCP utility</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: The newly generated feature can be added as a column to an existing table or stored in a new table and joined with the original table for machine learning.
trans-unit.target: The newly generated feature can be added as a column to an existing table or stored in a new table and joined with the original table for machine learning.

trans-unit.source: Features can be generated or accessed if already created, using the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure ML as shown below:
trans-unit.target: Features can be generated or accessed if already created, using the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure ML as shown below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>azureml readers</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>azureml readers</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Using Python to explore data and generate features when the data is in SQL Server is similar to processing data in Azure blob using Python as documented <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Using Python to explore data and generate features when the data is in SQL Server is similar to processing data in Azure blob using Python as documented <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The data needs to be loaded from the database into a pandas data frame and then can be processed further.
trans-unit.target: The data needs to be loaded from the database into a pandas data frame and then can be processed further.

trans-unit.source: We document the process of connecting to the database and loading the data into the data frame in this section.
trans-unit.target: We document the process of connecting to the database and loading the data into the data frame in this section.

trans-unit.source: The following connection string format can be used to connect to a SQL Server database from Python using pyodbc (replace servername, dbname, username and password with your specific values):
trans-unit.target: The following connection string format can be used to connect to a SQL Server database from Python using pyodbc (replace servername, dbname, username and password with your specific values):

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Pandas library</linkText><title></title> in Python provides a rich set of data structures and data analysis tools for data manipulation for Python programming.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Pandas library</linkText><title></title> in Python provides a rich set of data structures and data analysis tools for data manipulation for Python programming.

trans-unit.source: The code below reads the results returned from a SQL Server database into a Pandas data frame:
trans-unit.target: The code below reads the results returned from a SQL Server database into a Pandas data frame:

trans-unit.source: Now you can work with the Pandas data frame as covered in topics <linkText>Process Azure Blob data in you data science environment</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Now you can work with the Pandas data frame as covered in topics <linkText>Process Azure Blob data in you data science environment</linkText><title></title>.
